sentences.sentence: I could understand, as I saw the fury( 暴怒 ) and the passion( 激愤 ) of the man, that it was no unreasonable terror which had possessed Major Sholto when he first learned that the injured convict( 囚犯 ) was upon his track.
“You forget that we know nothing of all this,” said Holmes quietly. “We have not heard your story.”
“Well, sir, if you want to hear my story I have no wish to hold it back.
What I say to you is God’s truth, every word of it.
I am a Worcestershire man. My close relatives were all steady, church-going folk, small farmers, well known and respected over the countryside, while I was always a bit of a black sheep( 害群之马 ).
When I was about eighteen, I got into a mess over a girl, and could only get out of it again by joining the Army, which sent me over to India.
I was fool enough to go swimming in the Ganges. A crocodile( 鳄鱼 ) took off my right leg as clean as a surgeon( 外科医生 ) could have done it, just above the knee.

I was five months in hospital over it, and when at last I was able to limp( 跛行 ) out of it with this wooden leg strapped( 用带子系住 ) to my stump( 残肢 ), the Indian Army rebelled( 反叛 ) against the British.
One month India was as quiet and peaceful, to all appearance, as anywhere in England.
The next there were two hundred thousand black devils( 魔鬼 ) let loose( 不受控制 ), and the country was a perfect hell.
I just managed to escape, and found myself late at night ‘safe’ within the walls at Agra.
But we were not really safe there, either; we held just the ground that our guns commanded.

It was a fight of millions against hundreds, and the cruelest part was that these men we fought against were our own troops whom we had taught and trained, fighting with weapons( 武器 ) that we had given them.
Nothing but the worst news came to us from every side—in every direction there was nothing but torture( 酷刑 ) and murder and atrocity( 暴行 ).
We took up our position in the old fort( 城堡 ) at Agra.
I don’t know if any of you gentlemen have ever read or heard anything of that old fort( 城堡 ).
It is the queerest( 最为古怪的 ) place I ever was in, and I have been in some strange places.
First of all, it is enormous( 巨大的 ). There is a modern part, which accommodated our soldiers, women, children, stores, and everything else.
But the modern part is nothing like the size of the old part, where nobody goes, and which is abandoned to the scorpions and the centipedes.
It is all full of great deserted halls, and winding passages, and long corridors( 走廊 ) twisting in and out, so that it is easy enough for folk to get lost in it.
So people seldom went there, though now and again a party with torches( 火把 ) might go exploring.
The river washes along the front of the old fort( 城堡 ), and so protects it, but on the sides and behind there are many doors, and these had to be guarded, of course.
We organized a central guard-house in the middle of the fort( 城堡 ), and left one white man and two or three natives at each gate.
I was chosen to take charge during certain hours of the night of a small isolated( 偏僻的 ) door on the southwest side of the fort( 城堡 ).
Two Sikh soldiers were placed under my command, and I was told if anything went wrong to fire my rifle( 来复枪 ).
As the guard was a good two hundred yards away, however,
and as the space between was cut up into a maze( 错综复杂 ) of passages and corridors( 走廊 ), I had great doubts as to whether they could arrive in time to be of any use in case of an actual attack.
For two nights I kept the watch with my Sikhs.
They were tall, fierce-looking men, Mahomet Singh and Abdullah Khan by name.
They could talk English pretty well, but they preferred to talk together in their own language.
Every two hours the officer of the night used to come round to all the posts, to make sure that all was well.
The third night of my watch was dark, windy, and rainy.
I tried again and again to make my Sikhs talk, but without much success.
At two in the morning the rounds passed, and broke for a moment the weariness of the night.
I took out my pipe, and put down my rifle( 来复枪 ) to strike the match.
In an instant( 顷刻间 ) the two Sikhs were upon me.
One of them snatched my rifle( 来复枪 ) up( 夺取 ) and pointed it at my head, while the other held a great knife to my throat and swore he would kill me if I moved a step.
My first thought was they were rebels( 叛军 ), and that this was the beginning of an attack.
I opened my mouth to give a scream to warn the main guard.
The man who held me seemed to know my thoughts, for he whispered, ‘Don’t make a noise. The fort( 城堡 ) is safe enough. There are no rebels( 叛军 ) on this side of the river.’
There was the ring of truth( 真实可信 ) in what he said, and I knew that if I raised my voice I was a dead man.
So I waited to see what they wanted from me.
‘Listen to me, Sahib,’ said the taller and fiercer of the pair, the one whom they called Abdullah Khan.
‘Either you are heart and soul with us on your oath( 誓言 ) on the cross of the Christians, or your body this night shall be thrown into the ditch( 沟渠 ).
There is no middle way( 折中方法 ). Which is it to be, death or life?
We can only give you three minutes to decide, for all must be done before the rounds come again.’
‘How can I decide?’ said I. ‘You have not told me what you want of me.
But I tell you now that if it is anything against the safety of the fort( 城堡 ) I will have nothing to do with it, so you can kill me now.’
‘It is nothing against the fort( 城堡 ),’ said he. ‘We only ask you to do what you British came here for—to be rich.

If you will be one of us this night, we will swear to you upon the naked( 无鞘的 ) knife, and by the threefold( 三重的 ) oath( 誓言 ) which no Sikh was ever known to break, that you shall have your fair share of the loot( 战利品 ).
A quarter of the treasure shall be yours.’
‘But what is the treasure, then?’ I asked.
‘Will you swear,’ said he, ‘by the bones of your father, by the honor of your mother, by the cross of your faith, to raise no hand and speak no word against us, either now or afterwards( 以后 )?’
‘I will swear it,’ I answered, ‘provided that the fort( 城堡 ) is not endangered.’
‘Then my comrade and I will swear that you shall have a quarter of the treasure which shall be equally divided among the four of us.’
‘There are only three of us,’ said I.
‘No, Dost Akbar must have his share. We can tell the tale to you while we await( 等待 ) them.
I know that an oath( 誓言 ) is binding upon( 必须遵守 ) a Feringhee, and that we may trust you.
Had you been a lying Hindu, though you had sworn by all the gods in their false temples, your blood would have been upon the knife, and your body in the water.
But the Sikh knows the Englishman, and the Englishman knows the Sikh.’”

article_info.previous: Watson带着箱子来到了Miss Morstan的住处，并向她讲述了他们一路的经历。设法撬开箱子之后却发现箱子是空的，Watson感到心里的一块大石头落地，两人终于向对方表明了内心的情意。而后经过对Jonathan Small的审问，果然这空箱是他故意所为。

question.cn: 他是怎么失去他的右腿的？
question.en: How did he lose his right leg?

options.cn: 在游泳时被一条鳄鱼攻击。
options.en: He was attacked by a crocodile when swimming.
He was hit by a bullet during a war.

options.cn: 在一次交通事故中受了重伤。
options.en: He was seriously injured in a traffic accident.

analysis: 文中提到：“I was fool enough to go swimming in the Ganges. A crocodile took off my right leg as clean as a surgeon could have done it, just above the knee.”因此答案选A。

question.cn: 下列有关古堡的表述哪一项是正确的？
question.en: Which of the following statements about the old fort is CORRECT?

options.cn: 现代区域比古老区域大得多。
options.en: The modern part was much bigger than the old part.

options.cn: 人们只居住在古堡里的现代区域。
options.en: People only lived in the modern part of the fort.

options.cn: 人们经常去古老区域，因为那儿更安全。
options.en: People often went to the old part because it was safer.

analysis: 文中提到：“There is a modern part, which accommodated our soldiers, women, children, stores, and everything else. But the modern part is nothing like the size of the old part, where nobody goes, and which is abandoned to the scorpions and the centipedes. ”因此答案选B。

question.en: Who guarded the door together with him?

options.cn: 两个是锡克教徒的士兵。

analysis: 文中提到：“I was chosen to take charge during certain hours of the night of a small isolated door on the southwest side of the fort. Two Sikh soldiers were placed under my command, and I was told if anything went wrong to fire my rifle. ”因此答案选B。

question.cn: 这两个锡克教徒是叛军吗？

analysis: 文中说道：“My first thought was they were rebels, and that this was the beginning of an attack.”但是事实却不是这样，“‘It is nothing against the fort,’ said he. ‘We only ask you to do what you British came here for—to be rich. ”可知这两个人并不是要做危害城堡的事，因此答案选C。

question.cn: 根据教徒所说，他能得到什么回报？
question.en: What could he get in return according to the Sikhs?
